Description: Optimization problems where the objective function and constraints are linear. Aims to maximize or minimize a linear function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.
Solvability: Often solvable in polynomial time (efficient algorithms exist)

Description: Similar to LP, but requires some or all variables to be integers. Adds complexity.
Example: but heuristics and specialized algorithms exist)
Appearances: Assigning tasks to workers with binary (0 or 1) variables.

Description: Optimization problems where the objective function and constraint set are convex. Guarantees a global optimum.
Solvability: Often solvable efficiently (especially with interior-point methods)

Description: Breaking down a complex problem into smaller overlapping subproblems, solving each subproblem only once, and storing the solutions to avoid redundant computation.
Solvability: Solvable if the subproblems have optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems

Description: Problems dealing with discrete structures (combinations, permutations, graphs). Often involves finding the 'best' object from a finite set.
Solvability: NP-hard in many cases; uses heuristics

Description: Optimization problems where the objective function or constraints are nonlinear.
Solvability: Can be challenging; local optima are a concern; many different algorithms apply.

Description: Combines linear, integer, and nonlinear elements. Very general and powerful.
Optimization problems involving randomness or uncertainty. The data or parameters are not known with certainty.
Solvability: Complex; requires handling probabilities and expectations.

Description: A type of nonlinear optimization that can be transformed into a convex problem.
Solvability: Efficient algorithms exist for certain forms.

Description: Optimization problems with multiple conflicting objectives. Aims to find a set of Pareto-optimal solutions.
Solvability: Requires defining a preference function or using Pareto analysis.
